In 1728, Wellington'spaternalgrandfatherRichard Wesley, 1st Baron MorningtonRichard Colley, a landlord who lived at Rahin nearCarbury,County Kildare, changed his surname to Wesley.Longford (1971). p. 7.File:Coat of Arms of the Duke of Wellington.svg220pxthumbrightWellington'scoat of armsThe Colley or Cowley family had lived in that part of Kildare since the time of Wellington's ancestor, SirHenry Colley (died 1584)Henry Colleyor Cowley, who died before 2 October 1584.cite webLundyDarrylhttp://www.thepeerage.com/p10657.htm#i106566Sir Henry ColleyThe Peerage.com10 March 2012Unreliable source?yFebruary 2013Sir Henry in his lifetime possessed Carbury Castle, in north-west Kildare, starting with a 21-year lease in 1554.Lease dated 23 October 1554; Fiant no.53,Philip & Mary, cited in Appendix IV, 9th Report of the Deputy Keeper of Public Records in Ireland.Journal of the Kildare Archaeological Society, Vol. X, No. 1, pp. 9094.

Colley is a surname of English origin.cite webhttp://www.irishtimes.com/ancestor/surname/index.cfm?fuseactionSurname indexIrish Times17 March 2012However, Colley or Cowley is also an Anglicised form ofMac Amhalghaidh, a family who were lords ofClraighein Chalaid in what is nowCounty Westmeath.cite webhttp://www.libraryireland.com/names/maca/mac-amhalghadha-mac-amhalghaidh.phpMac AmhalghaidhLibrary of Ireland10 March 2012This family were claimed descent from the 5th-century Irish king,Niall of the Nine Hostages, and had the following genealogy ("m" indicates "son of"):

paragraph.template: quote<arg name="Amlaibh m Amlaibh m Muircertaigh m Aedha Finn m Maghnusa m Muircertaigh m Domnaill m Floinn m Aedha m '''Amhlaibh''' m Fergail m Con Coiccriche m Forannain m Suibhne m Domnaill m Ruairc m Cathusaigh m Aedha m Cuinn m Maoil Fhothaid m Criomthainn m Brenainn m Briain m Maine m Nell Noigiallaigh.<ref name">"clanmaclochlainn-ocleryms">{{cite web |url

article.paragraph: The preponderance of the evidence is that Wellington's family originated with John Cooley,lord of the manorofGlaston,Rutland, England, who was born around 1400. His son, Walter, born circa 1440, arrived in Drogheda, Ireland, about 1500.Ball. F. Elrington The Judges in Ireland 12211921 John Murray London 1926 Vol. 1 p.203Walter's sonRobert Cowley (judge)Robert Cowleywho becameMaster of the Rolls in IrelandBall p.203died in 1546 leaving a son,Walter Cowley,Principal Solicitor for Ireland, who appears to have been father to Sir Henry.Henry Colley married Katherine Cusack, daughter of SirThomas Cusack (Irish judge)Thomas Cusack,Lord Chancellor of Ireland. With this marriage began the Colley-Wellesley connection, since Sir Thomas was the son of John Cusack and his wife, Alison de Wellesley.Mosley, ed.Burke's Peerage107th Edition Delaware 2003 Vol.2 p.2971

article.heading: The Iron Duke
article.paragraph: This commonly used nickname originally related to his consistent political resolve rather than to any particular incident. In various cases its editorial use appears to be disparaging.cite webFreeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser (Dublin, Ireland)18 May 1832British Libraryhttp://newspapers.bl.uk/blcs/ British Newspapers 1800â€“190017 March 2012It is likely that its use became more widespread after an incident in 1832 in which he installed metal shutters to prevent rioters breaking windows at Apsley House.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/wellington_duke_of.shtml BBC History 27 February 2011The term may have been made increasingly popular byPunch (magazine)Punchcartoons published in 184445.cite webhttp://www.historytoday.com/re-foster/mr-punch-and-iron-duke Mr Punch and the Iron Duke R.E.Foster 29 May 2011Holmes (2002). pp. 285288, 302303.
Wellington had various other nicknames:

list.listitem: In the popular ballads of the day Wellington was called"Nosey"or"Old Nosey".cite bookRory MuirWellington: Waterloo and the fortunes of peace, 1814-1852https://books.google.com/books?id2013472

Alexander I, the Czar of Russia, was to call him"Le vainqueur du vainqueur du monde", the conqueror of the worlds conqueror, and the worlds conqueror was, of course, Napoleon.cite bookCornwell, BernardWaterloo â€“ The History of Four Days, Three Armies and Three Battles201410
Officers under his command called him"The Beau", as he was a fine dresser.Holmes (2002). p. 178.
Spanish troops called him"The Eagle", while Portuguese troops called him"DouroDouro"after his river crossing at Oporto in 1809.Morgan (2004). p. 135.
"Beau Douro"; Wellington found this amusing when hearing it used by a Colonel of the Coldstream Guards.

"Sepoy General"; Napoleon used this term as an insult to Wellington's military service in India, publicly considering him an unworthy opponent.cite webhttp://www.andrew-roberts.net/pages/books/napoleon_and_wellington.asp Roberts, Andrew Napoleon & Wellington 2 June 2011The name was used in the French newspaperLe Moniteur Universel, as a means of propaganda.Roberts (2003). pp. 74, 7879.
"The Beef"; It is a theory that theBeef Wellingtondish is a reference to Wellington, although some chefs dispute this.Scott, Wright (2006) p. 26.
